ai-dn1:1.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was traveling along the road between Rājagaha and Nālanda together with a large Saṅgha of around five hundred mendicants.
ai-dn1:1.1.3_0: The wanderer Suppiya was also traveling along the same road, together with his pupil, the brahmin student Brahmadatta.
ai-dn1:1.1.4_0: Meanwhile, Suppiya criticized the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in many ways,
ai-dn1:1.1.5_0: while his pupil Brahmadatta praises them in many ways.
ai-dn1:1.1.6_0: And so both teacher and pupil followed behind the Buddha and the Saṅgha of mendicants directly contradicting each other.
ai-dn1:1.2.1_0: Then the Buddha took up residence for the night in the royal rest-house in Ambalaṭṭhikā together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.
ai-dn1:1.2.2_0: And Suppiya and Brahmadatta did likewise.
ai-dn1:1.2.3_0: Meanwhile, Suppiya criticized the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in many ways,
ai-dn1:1.2.4_0: while his pupil Brahmadatta praises them in many ways.
ai-dn1:1.2.5_0: And so both teacher and pupil kept on directly contradicting each other.
ai-dn1:1.3.1_0: Then several mendicants rose at the crack of dawn and sat together in the pavilion, where the topic of evaluation came up:
ai-dn1:1.3.2_0: “It’s incredible, reverends, it’s amazing how the diverse attitudes of sentient beings have been clearly comprehended by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
ai-dn1:1.3.3_0: For this Suppiya criticizes the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in many ways,
ai-dn1:1.3.4_0: while his pupil Brahmadatta praises them in many ways.
ai-dn1:1.3.5_0: And so both teacher and pupil followed behind the Buddha and the Saṅgha of mendicants directly contradicting each other.”
ai-dn1:1.4.1_0: When the Buddha found out about this discussion on evaluation among the mendicants, he went to the pavilion,
ai-dn1:1.4.1_1: where he sat down on a prepared seat.
ai-dn1:1.4.1_2: and told the mendicants what had happened.
ai-dn1:1.4.2_0: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was unfinished?”
ai-dn1:1.4.3_0: When he said this, those mendicants said to the Buddha,
ai-dn1:1.4.4_0: “Sir, it’s because we rose at the crack of dawn and sat together in the pavilion, where the topic of evaluation came up:
ai-dn1:1.4.5_0: ‘It’s incredible, reverends, it’s amazing how the diverse attitudes of sentient beings have been clearly comprehended by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
ai-dn1:1.4.6_0: For this Suppiya criticizes the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in many ways,
ai-dn1:1.4.7_0: while his pupil Brahmadatta praises them in many ways.
ai-dn1:1.4.8_0: And so both teacher and pupil followed behind the Buddha and the Saṅgha of mendicants directly contradicting each other.’
ai-dn1:1.4.9_0: This is the conversation that was unfinished when the Buddha arrived.”
ai-dn1:1.5.1_0: “Mendicants, if others criticize me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, don’t make yourselves resentful, bitter, and exasperated.
ai-dn1:1.5.2_0: You’ll get angry and upset, which would be an obstacle for you alone.
ai-dn1:1.5.3_0: If others were to criticize me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, and you got angry and upset, would you be able to understand whether they spoke well or poorly?”
ai-dn1:1.6.1_0: “If others criticize me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, you should explain that what is untrue is in fact untrue:
ai-dn1:1.6.2_0: ‘This is why that’s untrue, this is why that’s false. There’s no such thing in us, it’s not found among us.’
ai-dn1:1.6.3_0: If others praise me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, don’t make yourselves thrilled, elated, and excited.
ai-dn1:1.6.4_0: You’ll get thrilled, elated, and excited, which would be an obstacle for you alone.
ai-dn1:1.6.5_0: If others praise me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, you should acknowledge that what is true is in fact true:
ai-dn1:1.6.6_0: ‘This is why that’s true, this is why that’s correct. There is such a thing in us, it is found among us.’
ai-dn1:1.7.1_0: When an ordinary person speaks praise of the Realized One, they speak only of trivial, insignificant details of mere ethics.
ai-dn1:1.7.2_0: And what are the trivial, insignificant details of mere ethics that an ordinary person speaks of?
ai-dn1:1.8.1_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up killing living creatures. He renounces the rod and the sword. He is scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings.’
ai-dn1:1.8.2_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.8.3_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up stealing. He take only what’s given, and expects only what’s given. He clean by not thieving.’
ai-dn1:1.8.4_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.8.5_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up unchastity. He is celibate, set apart, avoiding the common practice of sex.’
ai-dn1:1.8.6_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.9.1_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up lying. He speaks the truth and sticks to the truth. He’s honest and trustworthy, and doesn’t trick the world with his words.’
ai-dn1:1.9.2_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.9.3_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up divisive speech.
ai-dn1:1.9.3_1: He doesn’t repeat in one place what he heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, he reconciles those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.’
ai-dn1:1.9.4_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.9.5_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up harsh speech. He speaks in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.’
ai-dn1:1.9.6_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.9.7_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up talking nonsense. His words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. He says things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.’
ai-dn1:1.9.8_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.10.1_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama refrains from injuring plants and seeds.’
ai-dn1:1.10.3_0: ‘He eats in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.’
ai-dn1:1.10.4_0: ‘He refrains from dancing, singing, music, and seeing shows.’
ai-dn1:1.10.5_0: ‘He refrains from beautifying and adorning himself with garlands, perfumes, and makeup.’
ai-dn1:1.10.6_0: He refrains from high and luxurious beds.
ai-dn1:1.10.7_0: ‘He refrains from receiving gold and money,
ai-dn1:1.10.16_0: ‘He refrains from running errands and messages;
ai-dn1:1.10.20_0: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.’
ai-dn1:1.10.21_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.11.1_0: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in injuring plants and seeds.
ai-dn1:1.11.2_0: These include plants propagated from roots, stems, cuttings, or joints; and those from regular seeds as the fifth.
ai-dn1:1.11.3_0: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such injury to plants and seeds.’
ai-dn1:1.11.4_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.12.1_0: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in storing up goods for their own use.
ai-dn1:1.12.2_0: This includes such things as food, drink, clothes, vehicles, bedding, fragrance, and material possessions.
ai-dn1:1.12.3_0: The ascetic Gotama refrains from storing up such goods.’
ai-dn1:1.12.4_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.13.1_0: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in seeing shows.
ai-dn1:1.13.2_0: This includes such things as sofas, a collar, a wild bull, a pit, or a cliff, a swamp, and a sewer. She ropes, fancy them, quarrel, swepters, and swords; arrows fancy hair-makers, waste-removerstions.
ai-dn1:1.13.3_0: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such shows.’
ai-dn1:1.13.4_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.14.1_0: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in gambling that causes negligence.
ai-dn1:1.14.2_0: This includes such things as the ten powers of space, the tenth, the boil, the plows, and the earlier, the necklace, the tail, and the crystal, rubbish heaps, carpets, and shops.
ai-dn1:1.14.3_0: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such gambling.’
ai-dn1:1.14.4_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.15.1_0: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still make use of high and luxurious bedding.
ai-dn1:1.15.2_0: This includes such things as sofas, couches, woolen covers—shag-piled, colorful, white, embroidered with flowers, quilted, embroidered with animals, double-or single-fringed—and silk covers studded with gems, as well as silken sheets, woven carpets, rugs for elephants, horses, or chariots, antelope hide rugs, and spreads of fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red cushions at both ends.
ai-dn1:1.15.3_0: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such bedding.’
ai-dn1:1.15.4_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.16.1_0: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
ai-dn1:1.16.2_0: This includes such things as applying beauty products by anointing, massaging, bathing, and rubbing; mirrors, ointments, garlands, fragrances, and makeup; face-powder, foundation, bracelets, headbands, fancy walking-sticks or containers, rapiers, parasols, fancy sandals, turbans, jewelry, chowries, and long-fringed white robes.
ai-dn1:1.16.3_0: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such beautification and adornment.’
ai-dn1:1.16.4_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.17.1_0: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in unworthy talk. This includes such topics as
ai-dn1:1.17.2_0: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
ai-dn1:1.17.3_0: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such unworthy talk.’
ai-dn1:1.17.4_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.18.1_0: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in arguments.
ai-dn1:1.18.2_0: They say such things as: “You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!”
ai-dn1:1.18.3_0: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such argumentative talk.’
ai-dn1:1.18.4_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.19.1_0: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in running errands and messages.
ai-dn1:1.19.2_0: This includes running errands for rulers, ministers, aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or princes who say: “Go here, go there. Take this, bring that from there.”
ai-dn1:1.19.3_0: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such errands.’
ai-dn1:1.19.4_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.20.1_0: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in deceit, flattery, hinting, and belittling, and using material possessions to chase after other material possessions.
ai-dn1:1.20.2_0: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such deceit and flattery.’
ai-dn1:1.20.3_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.20.4_0: The midst of the Sangha is finished.
ai-dn1:1.21.1_0: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by unworthy branches of knowledge, by wrong livelihood. ...
ai-dn1:1.21.2_0: This includes the marks of a line drawn, by marks, reeds, bamboo, wood, resins, fruit, metals, and shells.
ai-dn1:1.21.3_0: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such unworthy branches of knowledge, such wrong livelihood.’
ai-dn1:1.21.4_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.22.1_0: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by unworthy branches of knowledge, by wrong livelihood. ...

ai-dn1:1.22.3_0: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such unworthy branches of knowledge, such wrong livelihood.’
ai-dn1:1.22.4_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.

ai-dn1:1.23.3_0: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such unworthy branches of knowledge, such wrong livelihood.’
ai-dn1:1.23.4_0: Because an ordinary person speaks of the Realized One.
ai-dn1:1.24.1_0: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by unworthy branches of knowledge, by wrong livelihood. ...

ai-dn1:1.27.6_0: The long chapter on ethics is finished.

ai-dn1:3.9.1_0: There are some ascetics and brahmins who are annihilationists. They assert the annihilation, eradication, and obliteration of an existing being on seven grounds.

ai-dn1:3.10.1_0: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin has this doctrine and view:
ai-dn1:3.10.2_0: ‘This self is physical, made up of the four primary elements, and produced by mother and father. Since it’s annihilated and destroyed when the body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death, that’s how this self becomes rightly annihilated.’

ai-dn1:3.11.7_0: ‘This self is annihilated and destroyed when the body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death:’ that’s how this self becomes rightly annihilated.’

ai-dn1:3.19.1_0: There are some ascetics and brahmins who speak of extinguishment in the present life. They assert the ultimate extinguishment of an existing being in the present life on five grounds.
ai-dn1:3.19.2_0: And what are the five grounds on which they rely?
ai-dn1:3.20.1_0: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin has this doctrine and view:
ai-dn1:3.20.2_0: ‘When this self amuses itself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation, that’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in the present life.’
ai-dn1:3.20.3_0: This is the ultimate extinguishment of an existing being in that very life.
ai-dn1:3.21.2_0: ‘*That* self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.
ai-dn1:3.21.3_0: Rather, this self has attained ultimate extinguishment in the present life.
ai-dn1:3.21.5_0: Because sensual pleasures are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. Their decay and perishing give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-dn1:3.21.6_0: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, this self enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. ai-dn1:3.21.7_0: This is the ultimate extinguishment of an existing being in that very life.

ai-dn1:3.22.6_0: But when the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, this self enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. ai-dn1:3.31.1_0: These are deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute. Those who make known after realizing them with their own insight. Those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.

ai-dn1:3.71.12_0: Now, when those ascetics and brahmins theorize about the past and the future on these sixty-two grounds, all of them experience this by repeated contact through the six fields of contact. Their feeling is a condition for craving. Craving is a condition for grasping. Grasping is a condition for continued existence. Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
ai-dn1:3.72.1_0: It’s when a mendicant truly understands the six fields of contact’s origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape. This is what they do.
ai-dn1:3.72.2_0: Any ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the past or the future do so on one or other of these sixty-two grounds. Outside of this there is none.
ai-dn1:3.72.3_0: Suppose a deft fisherman or his apprentice were to cast a fine-meshed net over a small pond.
ai-dn1:3.72.3_2: ‘Any sizable creatures in this pond will be trapped in the net.
ai-dn1:3.72.3_3: Wherever they emerge they are caught,
ai-dn1:3.72.3_4: Wherever they emerge they are caught and trapped in this very net.’
ai-dn1:3.72.4_0: In the same way, all of these ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the past or the future are trapped in the net of these sixty-two grounds, so that wherever they emerge they are caught and trapped in this very net.
ai-dn1:3.73.1_0: The Realized One’s body remains, but his attachment to rebirth has been cut off.
ai-dn1:3.73.2_0: As long as his body remains he will be seen by gods and humans.
ai-dn1:3.73.3_0: But when his body breaks up, after life has ended, gods and humans will see him no more.
ai-dn1:3.73.4_0: When the stalk of a bunch of mangoes is cut, all the mangoes attached to the stalk will follow along.
ai-dn1:3.73.5_0: In the same way, the Realized One’s body remains, but his attachment to rebirth has been cut off.
ai-dn1:3.73.6_0: As long as his body remains he will be seen by gods and humans.
ai-dn1:3.73.7_0: But when his body breaks up, after life has ended, gods and humans will see him no more.”
ai-dn1:3.74.1_0: When he had spoken, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:
ai-dn1:3.74.2_0: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! What is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”
ai-dn1:3.74.3_0: “Well, then, Ānanda, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Net of Meaning’, or else ‘The Net of the Teaching’, or else ‘The Prime Net’, or else ‘The Net of Views’, or else ‘The Supreme Victory in Battle’.”
ai-dn1:3.74.4_0: This is what the Buddha said.
ai-dn1:3.74.5_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-dn1:3.74.6_0: And while this discourse was being spoken, the galaxy shook.
